sen.j: 光明寺（こうみょうじ）は京都府綾部市にある真言宗醍醐派の寺院。
sen.e: Komyo-ji Temple is a temple of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect in Ayabe City, Kyoto.
Komyo-ji Temple, located in Ayabe City, Kyoto, is a temple of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.
Komyo-ji Temple, located in Ayabe City, Kyoto, is a temple of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.

sen.j: 山号は君尾山（きみのうさん）、本尊は千手観音菩薩。
sen.e: Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Kiminosan, and its principal icon is Senju Kannon Bosatsu (Thousand-Armed Kannon Buddhisattva, or a Buddhist Goddess of Mercy).

Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Kiminosan, and its principal icon is Senju Kannon Bosatsu (Thousand-Armed Kannon Buddhisattva, or a Buddhist Goddess of Mercy).

Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Kiminosan, and its principal image is Senju Kannon Bosatsu (Thousand-Armed Kannon Buddhisattva, or a Buddhist Goddess of Mercy).

sen.j: 599年、聖徳太子による開創と伝わる古刹。
sen.e: It is an ancient temple, and said to be founded by Prince Shotoku in 599.
An ancient temple, and said to have been founded in 599 by Prince Shotoku.
An ancient temple, and said to have been founded in 599 by Prince Shotoku.

sen.j: 国宝二王門
sen.e: Nio-mon gate (Deva gate) designated as a national treasure
The Nio-mon gate (Deva gate) is designated as a national treasure.
The Nio-mon gate (Deva gate) is designated as a national treasure.

sen.j: 三間一戸、入母屋造、栩葺の堂々たる二王門は白鳳8年（680年）建立されたものと伝わっていた。
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Nio-mon gate is a magnificent sangen-ikkomon gate (a 3x2-bay gate of an eight-legged style) of the irimoya style (a half-hipped roof) with a tochibuki roof (a type of board roofing in which boards are split along the straight grain and laid in such a way as to have a considerable overlap) has long been said to have been built in 680.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: しかし昭和25年（1950年）から昭和27年（1952年）10月まで行われた解体修理で、「宝治二年戊申」の墨書名と棟札が発見され、1248年の再建であることが明らかになった。
sen.e: The Nio-mon gate is a magnificent sangen-ikkomon gate (a 3x2-bay gate of an 8-legged style) of the irimoya style (a half-hipped roof) with a tochibuki roof (a type of board roofing whereby boards are split along the straight grain and laid in such a way as to have a considerable overlap) had long been said to be built in 680. However, when the gate was taken apart and repaired from 1950 to October 1952, ink writing saying "1248" and munafuda (a historical plaque on a building) were discovered, and it was revealed that the gate had been reconstructed in 1248.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Nio-mon gate is a magnificent sangen-ikkomon gate (a 3x2-bay gate of an eight-legged style) of the irimoya style (a half-hipped roof) with a tochibuki roof (a type of board roofing in which boards are split along the straight grain and laid in such a way as to have a considerable overlap) has long been said to have been built in 680. However, when the gate was taken apart and repaired from 1950 to October 1952, ink writing stating "1248" and munafuda (a historical plaque on a building) were discovered, and it was revealed that the gate had been reconstructed in 1248.

However, when the gate was taken apart and repaired from 1950 to October 1952, ink writing stating "1248" and munafuda (a historical plaque on a building) were discovered, and it was revealed that the gate had been reconstructed in 1248.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 併せて永正13年（1516年）、享保14年（1729年）、安政6年（1859年）の3度修理が行われていたことも判明した。
sen.e: In addition, it was also revealed that the gate was repaired three times in 1516, 1729 and 1859.
Additionally, it was revealed that the gate was repaired three times, in 1516, 1729 and 1859.
Additionally, it was revealed that the gate was repaired three times, in 1516, 1729 and 1859.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代初期築の二王（仁王）門は極めて稀少で、修理完工後の昭和29年（1954年）には新国宝に指定された。
sen.e: The Nio-mon gate was designated as a new national treasure in 1954 after it had been repaired because there were only a few number of Nio-mon gates built in the early Kamakura period.
The Nio-mon gate was designated as a new national treasure in 1954, even though it had been repaired, because only a few Nio-mon gates were built in the early Kamakura period.
The Nio-mon gate was designated as a new national treasure in 1954, after it had been repaired, because only a few Nio-mon gates were built in the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 599年 - 聖徳太子による開創。
sen.e: 599: Founded by Prince Shotoku.
599: Founded by Prince Shotoku
599: Founded by Prince Shotoku

sen.j: 673年 - 役小角が修験道の道場とする。
sen.e: 673: Enno Ozunu (En no Gyoja), who was a semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the 7 century, used the temple as a training hall for Shugendo, which is Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts.

673: Enno Ozunu (En no Gyoja), a semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the seventh century, used the temple as a training hall for Shugendo, which is Japanese mountain asceticism/shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts.

673: Enno Ozunu (En no Gyoja), a semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the seventh century, used the temple as a training hall for Shugendo, which is Japanese mountain asceticism/shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts.

sen.j: 680年 - 二王門建立。
sen.e: 680: Nio-mon gate was built.
680: Nio-mon gate was built.
680: Nio-mon gate was built.

sen.j: 平安時代延喜年間（900年頃） - 醍醐寺開祖の聖宝（理源大師）により真言密教の道場として中興された。
sen.e: Around 900 in Heian period: Restored by Shobo (Rigen Daishi) as a training hall for Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.
Around 900 in the Heian period: It was restored by Shobo (Rigen Daishi) as a training hall for Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.
Around 900 in the Heian period: It was restored by Shobo (Rigen Daishi), a founder of Daigo-ji Temple, as a training hall for Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.
sen.cmt: a founder of Daigo-ji Temple補足

sen.j: 以降室町時代にかけて山上山下72坊を有する巨刹へと発展した。
sen.e: After that, toward Muromachi period, the temple became a large temple with 72 temple buildings in Sanjo and Sange.
sen.cmt: 「山上」と「山下」は、SanjoおよびSangeと訳しました。「坊」は、temple buildingsと訳しました。
sen.e: Later, toward the Muromachi period, the temple became a large complex with 72 temple buildings in Sanjo and Sange.
Later, toward the Muromachi period, the temple became a large complex with 72 temple buildings in Sanjo and Sange.

sen.j: 1248年 - 二王門が再建される。
sen.e: 1248: Nio-mon gate was rebuilt.
1248: The Nio-mon gate was rebuilt.
1248: The Nio-mon gate was rebuilt.

sen.j: 1527年11月 - 兵火を受けて本堂、三重塔、法華堂、常行堂、鎮守拝殿、行者堂、鐘楼、坊舎を焼失。
sen.e: Nov. 1527: The main hall, a three-storied pagoda, Hokke-do Hall, Jogyo-do Hall, Haiden (a hall of offering and worship), Gyosha-do Hall, a bell tower and priests' living quarters were burnt down by war.

Nov. 1527: The main hall, a three-story pagoda, Hokke-do Hall, Jogyo-do Hall, Haiden (a hall of offering and worship), Gyosha-do Hall, a bell tower and priests' living quarters were burned down amid the ravages of war.

November 1527: The main hall, a three-story pagoda, Hokke-do Hall, Jogyo-do Hall, Haiden (a hall of offering and worship), Gyosha-do Hall, a bell tower and priests' living quarters were burned down amid the ravages of war.

sen.j: 1533年 - 上羽丹波守により再建。
sen.e: 1533: Rebuilt by Ueba-Tanba no kami (the governor of Ueba-Tanba Province).
1533: Rebuilt by Ueba-Tanba no kami (the governor of Ueba-Tanba Province)
1533: Rebuilt by Ueba-Tanba no kami (the governor of Ueba-Tanba Province)

sen.j: 1572年 - 明智光秀の焼き討ちにあう。
sen.e: 1572: Burnt by Mitsuhide AKECHI.
1572: Burned by Mitsuhide AKECHI
1572: Burned by Mitsuhide AKECHI

sen.j: 1579年 - 再び明智光秀の焼き討ちにあう。
sen.e: 1579: Burnt again by Mitsuhide AKECHI.
1579: Burned again by Mitsuhide AKECHI
1579: Burned again by Mitsuhide AKECHI

sen.j: 江戸時代 - 領主藤掛氏の庇護を受けたが、寺坊は漸減する。
sen.e: Edo period: Received the patronage of a feudal lord, Fujikake, but the number of temple buildings decreased gradually.
Edo period: It received the patronage of a feudal lord, Fujikake, but the number of temple buildings gradually decreased.
Edo period: It received the patronage of a feudal lord, Fujikake, but the number of temple buildings gradually decreased.

sen.j: 1733年 - 山下の23坊が焼失。
sen.e: 1733: Twenty-three temple buildings in Yamashita were burned down.
1733: Twenty-three temple buildings in Yamashita were burned down.
1733: Twenty-three temple buildings in Yamashita were burned down.

sen.j: 1836年 - 本堂が再建される。
sen.e: 1836: The main hall was rebuilt.
1836: The main hall was rebuilt.
1836: The main hall was rebuilt.

sen.j: 明治時代初頭 - 山上に残っていた4坊が無くなる。
sen.e: Early Meiji period: Four temple buildings that had remained in Sanjo were lost.
Early Meiji period: Four temple buildings that had remained in Sanjo were lost.
Early Meiji period: Four temple buildings that had remained in Sanjo were lost.

sen.j: 1914年 - 古建築の庫裏、方丈、客殿を焼失。
sen.e: 1914: Old kuri (priests' living quarters), hojo (an abbot's chamber), and kyakuden (a reception hall) were burnt down.
1914: The old kuri (priests' living quarters), hojo (an abbot's chamber) and kyakuden (a reception hall) were burned down.
1914: The old kuri (priests' living quarters), hojo (an abbot's chamber) and kyakuden (a reception hall) were burned down.

sen.j: 1916年 - 庫裏再建。
sen.e: 1916: Kuri was rebuilt.
1916: Kuri was rebuilt.
1916: Kuri was rebuilt.
